utterances: I would say most economists say there is not going to be much stimulus from the extension of those tax breaks for the wealthy in the near term, because they will save the money that they get back in taxes and not spend it, as will people in lower incomes.
And Ron Elving, getting back to the point you made before the president started to speak, the era of triangulation may be back with us.
In that last question, President Obama sounding more combative than he had at any other point in this news conference, saying: I want to speak to my Democratic friends.

Yes, meaning those Democratic friends who are currently incensed with me because I have not stuck with the position they wanted me to go right past the first of January with, drive the car over the cliff and say let's keep fighting this, let's let the American people focus on who wants tax cuts for millionaires and who wants tax cuts for people under $250,000, joint filers.
There are those who feel this is the time to join that struggle and see what happens.

The president said his North Star - and this is the positive side of the hostage-taker analogy, the positive side is he said: Our North Star has to be the well-being of the American economy and the American people.
And if that doesn't indicate that we should drive over the cliff, I'm not going to drive it.
You know...
Go ahead, Ari.
The president was pretty savvy in framing this as deal or no deal.
Either we get the package that I put on the table, or we get nothing, and the taxes go up for every American on January 1st.
I think there are people on the left who would say: You could have gotten a better deal than you did.

You could have either gotten a permanent extension of the taxes for - the tax benefits for parents of students and things like that, you could've gotten something along the lines of the DREAM Act, the START treaty, the don't ask, don't tell repeal.
And instead they think that the deal that the president got was far less than he could have accomplished in exchange for the two-year extension of the tax cuts for the wealthy.
And in fact he was asked a question: Might not you have wanted to get the agreement to raise the debt limit?
This is going to be a debate when Congress comes back in January, the new Congress.

And this is going to be a debate that's going to be, well, fascinating, because some of the new senators in particular have said they will vote against raising the debt limit for the United States, increasing the legal authority to borrow.
And the president said today: I will hold John Boehner to his word that nobody wants to see the full faith and credit of the United States go, well, down the tubes.
I think we can use that analogy.
Gentlemen, thank you very much: Ron Elving, Ari Shapiro, John Ydstie.
Stay tuned for more coverage of the president's remarks later today on NPR News.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
Those seeking to curb illegal immigration are also hard at work trying to keep the pressure on Washington.
In recent weeks a citizens action group called Grassfire.org sent out 700,000 petitions and faxes to the Senate protesting the immigration legislation.
Steven Elliott is the founder of Grassfire and he joins us now.
Welcome to the program.
Well, thank you very much.
Part of your campaign included an ad and it was a takeoff of the hamburger commercial from the 1980s, where the little old ladies would say, Where's the beef?
In your ad, there are three ladies, they're driving alongside the border.
Let's take a listen.
(Soundbite of ad)
Unidentified Man: Now Congress and the president want to give amnesty to millions of the illegal aliens instead of securing the border.
Call the president and Congress today and give them a message.
Unidentified Woman: Where's the fence?
Mr.
Elliott, this ad simplifies the entire matter of immigration down to this tagline, you know, these three words, when the legislation in question is 380 pages long.
It's incredibly complex.
How well do you think the people who you got to sign petitions and send faxes to senators actually understood what they were protesting?
Oh, they understood it very, very well.

That was the most fascinating thing about this debate and what we've learned from - what's happening now in citizen activism and citizen involvement; there's so many opportunities and so many ways for citizens to get information.
They digest it extremely well.
They understand what this Bush-Kennedy amnesty bill does, what it will do to our country if it is passed.
We just heard in Jennifer Ludden's story how immigrant rights groups are looking to regroup and march to the White House next week.
What does your organization, Grassfire, have planned next?
Well, we have an extensive campaign.

In fact, the news now with the president really pushing forward this bill and saying I'll see you at the bill signing, he's kind of thrown down the gauntlet once again and I can tell you that just in the last 24 hours, we've seen an incredible response from our team members who are quite disturbed by the president's posture on this issue.
His - I guess I could say arrogance on this issue.
We're concerned about his inability or unwillingness to listen to what the American people are saying on this issue, which is they do not want this bill passed.
What do you think is the most viable solution to deal with immigration?
Well, I think the most viable solution is to first secure our borders and enforce the current laws that we have on the books.
And that's what our ad - it really resonates with people because it says where's the fence?
Last year Congress and the president signed in the law a bill which authorized over 800 miles of fence.
And about 12 miles have been built and most of those are not even a double layer fence.
So I think what we have is a breakdown of trust with the American people.
But what plans might you have specifically?
You know, any plan is only going to go so far if it isn't accepted by both parties.
What do you think could possibly be proposed that would appease, you know, both sides of the aisle?
Well, I don't know that there is a plan of appeasement for this.
We're looking for a way to resolve the crisis of illegal immigration and restore law and order and restore national identity and national security for our nation.
So you don't care whether or not it makes it through the Senate.
You're standing by your plan.
It's that or nothing else as far as you're concerned.
Well, this plan, again, is a non-starter.

We're not opposed to any kind of overhaul of immigration reform, of our process, of dealing with the backlog, but when line one of page one of the bill gives irrevocable amnesty to every illegal alien in this country, it's a non-starter.
We can't even begin to discuss this bill as far as what we would do to modify it, to make it acceptable.
Steven Elliot is the founder of Grassfire.org.
Thanks for joining us.
Thank you.
It seems like a stunning reversal for a president who constantly talks about China stealing American jobs.
Donald Trump now says he wants to save jobs in China.
Today, the president tweeted - President Xi of China and I are working together to give massive Chinese phone company ZTE a way to get back into business fast.
President Trump goes on to tweet - too many jobs in China lost.
Commerce Department has been instructed to get it done.

Well, just last month, the administration banned shipments of American technology to ZTE for seven years on the grounds that the Chinese electronics giant violated a settlement over illegal shipments to North Korea and Iran.
And then last week, the company said it would cease major operations because of the U.S.
trade restrictions.
Roger Cheng of CNET is following the story.
He joins us via Skype.
Thanks for joining us, Roger.
Thanks for having me.
So just to recap for us.
What is ZTE, and what is its business model?
Sure.
ZTE is one of the world's largest telecommunications equipment maker.
In addition to making network equipment for cellphone services, they also create smartphone themselves.
In fact, they are the fourth-largest smartphone maker in the U.S.
You probably don't recognize the name, but they make a lot of budget phones that show up at Boost Mobile or Cricket Wireless.
And so they're actually fairly popular here in the U.S.
All right.
Well, tell us, how did ZTE violate U.S.
sanctions on North Korea and Iran?
So that probably means the end of this week, or more likely next week.
They've got a deal to limit the amendments.
The Republicans will not have endless amendments coming to the floor.
But they still need 60 votes for cloture.
That's the vote to cut off debate.
And we just don't know if they've got those votes yet.
Donald Trump has created a toxic environment.
And a toxic environment has allowed his supporters and those who sometimes seek confrontation to come together in violence.
There is no place for this.
That phrase there is no place for this figured in Hillary Clinton's reaction as well.

Marco Rubio on CNN this morning said he's finding it harder and harder every day to pledge to back Trump if he's the eventual nominee, although he hasn't come right out and said he's going to break his pledge to back whoever the Republican nominee is.
Here's some of Ted Cruz's reaction.
He said when you have a campaign that disrespects the voters that affirmatively encourages violence, you create an environment that only encourages this sort of nasty discourse.
And of course Bernie Sanders was in the Chicago area last night speaking out about this, blaming the incitement to violence that's in Trump's own speeches for what happened.
And you mentioned earlier, Ron, that Donald Trump's line is that he doesn't condone violence.
But of course there have been numerous examples at his rallies where he has used language, fiery rhetoric, that many say is bringing on exactly the kinds of incidents like we saw in Chicago.
Yes, it has been building up.
There was a major disturbance earlier in the day that didn't get nearly as much attention in St. Louis, but there were more than 30 arrests made there.
So we're clearly into the next phase of something and quite possibly not the last phase of it.
We've seen protesters escorted out of Trump rallies for months.
It almost became theatrical, part of the regular script.
At some point, a protester would appear, shout, could barely be heard, then the crowd would start to chant U.S.A., U.S.A., and Trump would say get him out.

And in fact, there was a moment this morning just outside of Dayton at that airport where he had said something very similar - just about one or two people who were holding up signs - get him out of here, get him the hell out of here.
And at one point in one of his rallies he said knock the crap out of them.
I promise you I will pay the legal fees.
I promise you.
And remembering the good old days when protesters would be carried out on a stretcher I believe were his words.
Big question here, Ron, is how much of an impact any of this might have on Donald Trump heading into Tuesday's primaries.
You know, it's hard to imagine it won't have an impact, but it's trickier to say just exactly what impact it's going to have.

There will be those who see these videos and see all this coverage on television, and they will decide that the whole Trump phenomenon that we've been seeing for the past year has gotten out of control.
There will be those who see these same coverages on television and think the country needs Donald Trump more than ever.
OK, NPR's Ron Elving.
Ron, thanks so much.
Thank you, Melissa.
Some people rely on borrowing money from themselves.
You get a payday loan.
It's cash you promise to pay back when your next paycheck arrives.

The Trump administration has been scaling back enforcement of this industry, and Kathy Kraninger, who runs the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, will likely be asked why when she testifies before a House panel today.
Here's NPR's Daniella Cheslow.
(SOUNDBITE OF DRAWER CLOSING AND KEYS JANGLING)
(Counting out bills, unintelligible).
This is the sound of a payday loan, cash you can get quickly just by walking into a store.
I'm at this Springfield, Va., branch of Advance America during a rainy lunch hour, and a woman who works as a medical assistant comes in.
I borrowed $300.
Interest is $73.
